head.title: Toward Better Care for the Old

hedline.hl1: Toward Better Care for the Old

abstract.p: Letter from Dennis Rivera, president of 1199, nation's largest health care union, says nursing home work ranks as one of highest for occupational hazards and short-staffing only makes dangers worse (Aug 7 editorial)

block.p: Nursing home work ranks among the most dangerous occupations in the country. And short-staffing only makes the dangers worse. Caregivers pay a personal price with back injuries and other occupational hazards that contribute to the industry's extraordinarily high turnover.

Nursing home work ranks among the most dangerous occupations in the country. And short-staffing only makes the dangers worse. Caregivers pay a personal price with back injuries and other occupational hazards that contribute to the industry's extraordinarily high turnover.

We, the nation's largest health care union, are working to achieve accountability through minimum nursing home staffing standards; mandatory public disclosure of staffing levels; directly linking government reimbursement levels with staffing levels; ensuring adequate financing levels; and providing more training for caregivers.
DENNIS RIVERA President, 1199 New York, Aug. 10, 2000
